questions.prompt: A relation R on set A is reflexive if:
options: For all a ∈ A: (a, a) ∉ R
For all a ∈ A: (a, a) ∈ R
There exist a, b such that (a, b) ∈ R
For all a, b ∈ A: if (a, b) ∈ R then (b, a) ∈ R
questions.explanation: A relation is reflexive if every element is related to itself. For all a in A, (a, a) must be in R.

questions.prompt: The relation "less than" (<) on integers is reflexive.
questions.explanation: No, because no integer is less than itself. For reflexivity, we would need n < n for all n, which is false.

questions.prompt: A relation R on set A is symmetric if:
options: For all a, b ∈ A: if (a, b) ∈ R then (b, a) ∈ R
For all a ∈ A: (a, a) ∈ R
For all a, b, c ∈ A: if (a, b) ∈ R and (b, c) ∈ R then (a, c) ∈ R
For all a ∈ A: (a, a) ∉ R
questions.explanation: A relation is symmetric if whenever a is related to b, then b is also related to a.

questions.prompt: Which property does the relation "less than" (<) on integers NOT have?
questions.explanation: The < relation is not reflexive because no number is less than itself. It IS transitive (a<b and b<c implies a<c), antisymmetric, and irreflexive.

questions.prompt: If a relation is both symmetric and antisymmetric, then it can only contain pairs of the form (a, a).
questions.explanation: If (a, b) is in R with a ≠ b, symmetry requires (b, a) ∈ R, but antisymmetry then requires a = b. Contradiction. So only (a, a) pairs are possible.

questions.prompt: Which combination of properties defines an equivalence relation?
questions.explanation: An equivalence relation must be reflexive (aRa), symmetric (aRb implies bRa), and transitive (aRb and bRc implies aRc).

questions.prompt: An equivalence relation partitions a set into disjoint equivalence classes.
questions.explanation: True. Every equivalence relation creates a partition of the set into disjoint equivalence classes, where each element belongs to exactly one class.

questions.prompt: Which combination of properties defines a partial order?
questions.explanation: A partial order is reflexive, antisymmetric, and transitive. Example: ≤ on integers, ⊆ on sets.

questions.prompt: The relation "is a sibling of" on a set of people (excluding oneself) is:
questions.explanation: You are not your own sibling (not reflexive), but if A is B's sibling, B is A's sibling (symmetric). It's not transitive (siblings of siblings might be the same person, not siblings).

questions.prompt: The equivalence class containing element a is denoted [a] and contains all elements b such that ____ is in R.
questions.explanation: The equivalence class [a] = {b ∈ A : (a, b) ∈ R} = {b ∈ A : a R b}.

questions.prompt: The transitive closure of a relation R is:
options: The smallest transitive relation containing R
The largest relation contained in R
The smallest symmetric relation containing R
The smallest reflexive relation containing R
questions.explanation: The transitive closure is the smallest transitive relation that contains R. It adds all pairs needed to make R transitive.

questions.prompt: In a total order (linear order), every two distinct elements are comparable.
questions.explanation: A total order is a partial order where for any a, b, either a ≤ b or b ≤ a. All elements are comparable (no incomparable pairs).

questions.prompt: If R is an equivalence relation on a set of 10 elements and creates 3 equivalence classes, what can we say?
options: The sum of the sizes of the classes is 10
At least one class has 10 elements
questions.explanation: Equivalence classes partition the set, so every element belongs to exactly one class. The sizes must sum to 10.

questions.prompt: The composition R ∘ S of relations R and S contains (a, c) if:
options: There exists b such that (a, b) ∈ R and (b, c) ∈ S
There exists b such that (a, b) ∈ S and (b, c) ∈ R
questions.explanation: For composition R ∘ S, we apply S first then R. So (a, c) ∈ R ∘ S if there exists b with (a, b) ∈ S and (b, c) ∈ R.

questions.prompt: The inverse relation R⁻¹ contains (b, a) if and only if (a, b) ∈ R.
questions.explanation: The inverse relation R⁻¹ = {(b, a) : (a, b) ∈ R}. It reverses all the ordered pairs in R.
